com.intland.codebeamer.utils

Class AnchoredPeriod

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.intland.codebeamer.utils.AnchoredPeriod
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable

    public class AnchoredPeriod
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.io.Serializable
    An anchored period defines a time period defined in a number of CalendarUnit relative to an anchor date.
    See Also:
    Serialized Form

    • Nested Class Summary

      Nested Classes 
      Modifier and Type Class and Description
      static class  AnchoredPeriod.Anchor

      A special StringDecoder for AnchoredPeriod definitions, see decode(String)

      An edge of an AnchoredPeriod: Either the begin or the end

      • getEdges

        public java.util.Date[] getEdges(java.util.Date anchorDate,
                        java.util.TimeZone timezone)
        Get the absolute begin and end date of this period according to the anchor date and timezone.
        Parameters:
        anchorDate - is the anchor date, or null to use the current system date
        timezone - is the TimeZone to calculate the relative period offset, or null to use default TimeZone
        Returns:
        an array with two dates, first is the begin, second is the end date

      • getEdge

        public java.util.Date getEdge(AnchoredPeriod.Edge edge,
                     java.util.Date anchorDate,
                     java.util.TimeZone timezone)
        Get the specified edge (begin or end date) of this period according to the anchor date and timezone.
        Parameters:
        edge - is the requested edge
        anchorDate - is the anchor date, or null to use the current system date
        timezone - is the TimeZone to calculate the relative period offset, or null to use default TimeZone
        Returns:
        the requested edge date, or null if edge was null

      • decode

        public static AnchoredPeriod decode(java.lang.String definition)
        Decode an anchored period definition string: "[anchor] [size] [unit]"

        The special definitions "today", "tomorrow" and "yesterday" are also recognized.

        If you do not specify an anchor, the default anchor is AnchoredPeriod.Anchor.Current, unless you specify a size, in which case the anchor is AnchoredPeriod.Anchor.Last if the size is negative, AnchoredPeriod.Anchor.Next otherwise.

        If you do not specify a unit, the default is CalendarUnit.Day.

        Note: According to the AnchoredPeriod.Anchor definition, "Next [1] [day|week|month|...]" should be interpreted as AnchoredPeriod.Anchor.Next one CalendarUnit, but because this would be equivalent to "This [day|week|month|...]" and also to "Last [day|week|month|...]", which seems unlogically, "Next [1] ..." and "Last [1] ..." is translated into AnchoredPeriod.Anchor.Future one unit and AnchoredPeriod.Anchor.Past one unit respectively.

        Parameters:
        definition - of the anchored period to decode (case is not significant)
        Returns:
        the decoded AnchoredPeriod
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if definition is not empty and not an valid anchored period definition
